conclusion: The problem involves determining the height \( H \) above the ground at which a fire extinguishing projectile hits a high-rise building, using principles of kinematics.

The image shows a fire truck equipped with an electromagnetic railgun (1) and a diagram (2) illustrating the projectile's motion towards a high-rise building with parameters \( L \), \( v_0 \), and \( \theta \).
The initial velocity \( v_0 = 50 \, \mathrm{m/s} \) is broken into horizontal (\( v_{x0} \)) and vertical (\( v_{y0} \)) components using trigonometric functions.
The horizontal velocity component is calculated as \( v_{x0} = 50 \cdot 0.6 = 30 \, \mathrm{m/s} \).
The vertical velocity component is calculated as \( v_{y0} = 50 \cdot 0.8 = 40 \, \mathrm{m/s} \).
The horizontal motion equation \( x = v_{x0} t \) is used to solve for the time \( t \) it takes for the projectile to reach the building.
The time is calculated as \( t = \frac{60}{30} = 2 \, \mathrm{s} \).
The vertical motion equation \( y = v_{y0} t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \) is used to calculate the height \( y \) at time \( t = 2 \, \mathrm{s} \).

Substituting \( t = 2 \, \mathrm{s} \), \( v_{y0} = 40 \, \mathrm{m/s} \), and \( g = 10 \, \mathrm{m/s}^2 \), the height is calculated as \( y = 40 \cdot 2 - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 10 \cdot (2)^2 = 80 - 20 = 60 \, \mathrm{m} \).
The final height \( H \) above the ground at which the projectile hits the high-rise building is determined to be \( H = 60 \, \mathrm{m} \).
